back: Given a $n \times n$ matrix $\mathbf{M}$, a non-zero vector $\mathbf{v}$ is an eigenvector of $\mathbf{M}$ if \begin{equation*} \mathbf{M} \mathbf{v} = \lambda \mathbf{v} \end{equation*} for some constant $\lambda$.

Given a $n \times n$ matrix $\mathbf{M}$, if $\mathbf{v}$ is an eigenvector of $\mathbf{M}$, then the corresponding eigenvalue is the constant $\lambda$ such that \begin{equation*} \mathbf{M} \mathbf{v} = \lambda \mathbf{v}. \end{equation*}

Given a $n \times n$ matrix $\mathbf{M}$, the characteristic equation is \begin{equation*} \det \left(\mathbf{M} - \lambda \mathbf{I} \right) =0, \end{equation*} which can be used to solve for the eigenvalues ($\lambda$).
For a square matrix $\mathbf{M}$, the matrix whose columns are the eigenvectors of $\mathbf{M}$.

Suppose $\mathbf{M}$ is a real $n \times n$ matrix with modal matrix $\mathbf{V}$ and eigenvalue matrix $\boldsymbol{\Lambda}$. If $\mathbf{V}$ has full rank, then the eigendecomposition (diagonalization) of $\mathbf{M}$ is \begin{equation*} \mathbf{M}= \mathbf{V} \boldsymbol{\Lambda}\mathbf{V}^{-1} . \end{equation*}
If $\mathbf{M}$ has an eigendecomposition with eigenvalues $\lambda_i$ then \begin{equation*} \det \mathbf{M} = \prod_{i} \lambda_{i} . \end{equation*}
